There were 4 at the ë‹µë™ ì§€ë¶€, when our family was baptized.
Similar in age, within a grade or two in school, we all had 2 to 3 siblings.
Our families formed the core of the Branch.
Then 3 years later, our family moved to eastern US.
Shortly thereafter, J family moved to Seattle Area.
Both of us served missions stateside. Elder J in Chicago and I served in CLAM.
Lost contact with the 2 Lees that stayed in Korea.
Then, one of the Lees came for his MBA at BYU.
Once he returned to Korea, we seldom spoke.
The other Lee came to the local Korean congregation that meets in Orem.
We met for a lunch.
He filled me in on those pioneering families of the ì¸ì²œ ä»å· area.
He also recounted the struggles and challenges of being a member in Korea. Along with businesses that failed.
Eventually he chose to migrate to US and settle in Richmond, VA.
Reached out to my friend J in Seattle, the one that is up-to-date on status of the 4 members from Incheon. He asked the MBA Lee if he can meet when we visit Korea.
The came back quickly and emphatically, YES!
It was delightful to hear his voice and plan our visit back that home of our youth/childhood. An anticipation of seeing old places of memories and hopes of meeting childhood friends and acquaintances.
Perhaps, some of the themes in the Korean Lyrics/Folk Songs will be realized on this trip.
Likewise I hope that the ways will be provided that will link and reunite families that were originally from North Korea.
I hope to contact my extended families and we will mend our differences and create new memories
By talking of Christ and His Gospel and talk of families members that are no longer here.
Partially fulfilling this verse in Revelation, Chapter 24.

title: A Noble Gathering
text:
The local Recreation Center hosted a 2-hour event.
It was held at the same location, where Seniors gather.
Participants arrived, dressed appropriately for the event.
Men in formal attire, with ties.
Women in dresses of various styles and colors.
It was a Daddy Daughter Dance event.



Turmoils and uncertainties are ever present and are part of modern life.

What makes a strong country?
A thriving community?

It begins with a family.
Women that will raise up a strong and compassionate leaders. And Men who knew priorities in life
Noble men and women of Provo, thank you for your example.

It is more noble to give yourself completely to one individual than to labor diligently for the salvation of the masses.

Dag Hammarskjold

title: Welcome Home
section: Open AI Explanation of Special Relativity
text:
Open AI Explanation of Special Relativity
The difference in years for an astronaut traveling at near-light speed and then returning to Earth is explained by Einsteinâ€™s Theory of Relativity, specifically Special Relativity and the concept of time dilation.

Key Concept: Time Dilation
Time dilation means that time passes at different rates for observers moving relative to each other. According to Einsteinâ€™s Special Relativity:

As an object moves faster, time slows down for it relative to an observer at rest.
The effect becomes dramatic as the object approaches the speed of light.



The Thought Experiment: The Twin Paradox
Imagine a twin astronaut traveling on a spaceship near the speed of light (say, 99.9% of the speed of light) and then returning to Earth.

During the journey:

The astronautâ€™s clock (inside the spaceship) runs much slower compared to a clock on Earth.
To the astronaut, time feels normal, but for observers on Earth, the astronaut is aging much more slowly.

When the astronaut returns to Earth:

Because time was moving slower for the astronaut, they may have aged only a few years.
Meanwhile, much more time has passed on Earthâ€”possibly decades or even centuries.




Why It Happens

Space and time are not absolute; they are interconnected in spacetime.
High speeds cause space contraction and time dilation, effects predicted and confirmed by relativity.



Conclusion
If an astronaut were to travel at near-light speeds for what feels like a few years for them, they could return to Earth and find that many more years (even centuries) have passed here. This is a real effect and has been experimentally confirmed using high-speed particles and precise atomic clocks.

title: Money Supply and Inflation
text:
M1 vs.Â M2 Money Supply: Key Differences and Impact on Inflation
The M1 and M2 money supplies both measure the amount of money circulating in an economy, but they focus on different types of liquidity.






Key Differences Between M1 and M2


Feature
M1
M2




Definition
Includes the most liquid forms of money.
Includes M1 plus less liquid savings instruments.


Components
Currency in circulation, checking accounts, Other liquid deposits
Everything in M1, Savings Accounts, Money Market Accounts, Small Time Deposits (CDs under $100k)


Liquidity
Highly liquid (readily available for transactions)
Less liquid (requires additional steps to access)


Purpose
Used primarily for immediate spending.
Represents money that can be saved but is still accessible.


Volatility
More volatile; reacts quickly to economic changes.
More stable; reflects longer-term savings behavior.








Impact on Inflation

M1 and Inflation:


A rapid increase in M1 often signals rising consumer spending, which can push demand higher and contribute to demand-pull inflation.
Conversely, a sharp decrease in M1 may reflect reduced spending power, which can slow economic growth.


M2 and Inflation:


Growth in M2 is more closely linked to longer-term inflation trends since it reflects both spending and savings behavior.
A sharp rise in M2 may indicate excess liquidity, which can eventually spill into consumer prices.



Example Scenario:

If the Federal Reserve increases the money supply (M1) rapidly, consumers may spend more, driving up demand for goods and services. Without an increase in supply, this can raise prices, causing inflation.
On the other hand, a spike in M2 might show that people are saving more, potentially delaying inflation but signaling future spending capacity.



Key Insight

M1 is a better short-term indicator of spending patterns.
M2 provides a broader view of money growth and its potential long-term impact on inflation.




M1 Supply and Consumer Price Index (CPI)
From Federal Reserve Bank of St Louis

M1 Supply (https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/M1SL)
Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers: All Items in U.S. City Average (CPIAUCSL) (https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/CPIAUCSL)





























































Does M1 Money Supply Predict Inflation or Vice Versa
The M1 money supply and inflation are closely linked, but the relationship is complex â€” one does not always predict the other in a straightforward way. Hereâ€™s how the interaction generally works:

1. M1 Growth as a Predictor of Inflation

M1 Expansion â†’ Inflation Risk:

When the M1 supply rises rapidly, it often signals increased consumer spending. If demand outpaces the supply of goods and services, demand-pull inflation can occur.
Example: During economic stimulus periods, expanded M1 may lead to higher prices if consumer spending surges.

âœ… M1 growth tends to lead inflation â€” but only if spending activity rises faster than supply.


2. Inflation Influencing M1

Inflation â†’ Higher M1 Demand:

In inflationary periods, consumers may keep more funds in liquid forms (like checking accounts) to cope with rising prices, which can inflate M1 figures.
Example: In times of high inflation, people may reduce savings in long-term deposits (M2) and instead hold more cash or liquid assets (M1) to maintain spending flexibility.

âœ… Inflation can increase M1 as people adjust financial habits.


3. Situations Where the Link Breaks

Velocity of Money: If M1 rises but money velocity (the rate money circulates in the economy) falls, inflation may not follow.
Supply Chain Factors: Inflation can also spike due to supply-side shocks (e.g., oil crises, labor shortages) without direct M1 changes.



Historical Example:

2020â€“2021 (Pandemic Stimulus Era):
The U.S. M1 supply surged due to stimulus payments and loose monetary policy.
Initially, inflation remained low because consumers saved more and spent cautiously.
By late 2021, when spending increased, inflation spiked sharply.




Conclusion:

M1 growth is often a leading indicator of inflation, but its predictive power depends on consumer behavior, economic conditions, and supply-side factors.
Inflation can also reshape M1 patterns as people shift toward more liquid assets

section: Practice of giving a masculine names to girls
text:
Practice of giving a masculine names to girls
Yes, there is a well-documented Korean tradition of giving masculine names to girlsâ€”especially in earlier generationsâ€”based on cultural and superstitious hopes for male offspring or to protect the child from misfortune. This tradition reflects aspects of Confucian values, family lineage priorities, and folk beliefs in historical Korea.

title: Whatâ€™s My Name
text:
ğŸ“œ Background and Cultural Context

ğŸ”¹ 1. Preference for Sons
In traditional Korean (and broader East Asian) society:

Sons were preferred for carrying on the family name, ancestral rites, and economic support.
Families hoping for a son might name a first-born daughter with a masculine name as a kind of â€œplaceholderâ€ or luck-bringing gesture to bring about the birth of a son next.


Example: Naming a girl â€œSang-chulâ€ (ìƒì² ), a name typical for boys, to trick spirits or fate.




ğŸ”¹ 2. Protective Naming: â€œMisnamingâ€
There was also a superstitious belief that evil spirits could target or harm precious children. By giving a girl a boyâ€™s name or a rough/common name:

The child might avoid spiritual attention or harm.
It would protect the childâ€™s life and future.

This overlaps with similar practices in other cultures (e.g., Russian peasants giving babies â€œuglyâ€ names to ward off spirits).



ğŸ”¹ 3. Practical Effects
Some women continued using their masculine names legally or socially for decades. Youâ€™ll find:

Women born in the 1930sâ€“60s with names like Young-ho, Dong-soo, or Chul-soo.
Occasionally, feminine names with strong, masculine syllables (like Sun-chul, Jong-il) that were family-chosen rather than self-selected.




ğŸ”¹ 4. Decline of the Practice
Since the 1980s and 1990s, this tradition has largely faded:

Changing gender norms
Decline in son preference
Rise of gender-neutral or Western-inspired Korean names like Ji-min, Ji-woo, Ha-eun

The name June for the summer month has its roots in ancient Rome, and itâ€™s generally believed to be named after the Roman goddess Juno, though there are alternate theories as well.

Juno was the Roman goddess of:

Because of her associations with marriage and fertility, June became a favored month for weddingsâ€”a tradition that still holds in many cultures today.

ğŸ”¹ Latin: Iunius mensis = â€œMonth of Junoâ€




ğŸ“œ 2. Alternative Theory: Iuniores (Younger People)
Roman scholar Ovid (in Fasti, his calendar poem) gives two possibilities:

That May (Maius) was named for maiores (elders),
And June (Iunius) for iuniores (youth).


â€œMaius a maioribus, iunioribusque Iuniusâ€ â€œMay from the older men, and June from the younger.â€

But this is considered more literary than historically grounded.

The ones he took with an iPhone.
It was a great set of photos, taken from the South Rim as the shadows from the setting sun highlighted the Canyon.
I had to agree with him, this old DSLR would not take better photos, if the comparison was based on the visual representation.
However, there is one thing, a limitation of the phone based camera.
One cannot take a technically bad photo.
That option is no longer available.
And if one canâ€™t take a bad photo how does one learn about
A manual transmission, often called a stick shift, is a type of gearbox used in vehicles that requires the driver to manually change gears using a clutch pedal and a gear stick (or shift lever).
Manual transmissions have seen a significant decline in the U.S. automotive market over the past few decades. In 1995, approximately 26.8% of vehicles sold at CarMax featured manual transmissions. In 2018 that figure dropped to 3.7%
There has been a resurgence driven by younger drivers seeking a more engaging driving experience and a sense of nostalgia along with enthusiasts that continue to seek them out for the control and driving pleasure they offer.2
Learned to drive a stick shift on streets of El Pueblo de Nuestra SeÃ±ora la Reina de los Ãngeles de PorciÃºncula,
Because Koreans were scattered throughout the mission and some outside the county, we were given an car, with an automatic transmission - A Chevrolet Chevette3.
Initially, my senior companion, with 6 months remaining, drove exclusively around K-Town as well as many locations that required freeway driving.
There was another set of Korean-speaking elders that covered the south half of the mission, that is mainly LA county and some of the Orange county.
They also had a Chevette but their tan version had a manual transmission.
Elder C from Hawaii suggested I learn how to drive it.
No pre-training, we just drove around the streets of Bellflower and Norwalk and hoped I would learn.
In the beginning, stalled out the engine due to improper timing between the clutch pedal and the stick shift.
But after making a few drivers upset along the Rosecrans Avenue, I got the hang of it.
Didnâ€™t have a car during college years.
Going back to college, as a graduate student, my parents bought a car for me.
Opted for a Subaru Station Wagon, a DL model with a 4WD, well suited for Utah.
The car served me well with its ample cargo space, when 2nd row seats were folded down.
However when Sister K married me, she didnâ€™t know how to drive a manual transmission.
Gave an effort to teach her but I was not as efficient nor patient as Elder C.
We didnâ€™t get very far, Sister K enlisted help of a her friend and she could drive the Subaru while I was at school.
When we bought, with help from our parents, a Mercury Villager, Sister K was elated.
She could take children to school and was free from the clutch and stick routine.
Much like the Artificial Intelligence aided, enabled understanding and task completion, the essential part of growth and learning has been eliminated.
These days, it is difficult to kill an engine while driving.
Even if one was able to override the algorithm and take a bad shot, it would be difficult to pin-point what contributed to photos being out of focus.
That agency or choice is not available in press-button photo taking and AI generated answers.
In taking or making photos, like in other efforts in life, mistakes will be made.
In those mistakes, lessons are given and learned.
The gentleman that sold me the Nikon camera said,
9 months into owning the camera, there are buttons, settings and mirrors that I havenâ€™t used.
Several times, I was tempted to use the automatic mode.
Sadly Nikon doesnâ€™t provide that mode, closest mode is the Aperture Mode.
I had to learn, or re-learn, the inter-relationship of the aperture opening, shutter speed and the light sensitivity as measured in ISO.4
Photos taken with this camera has a number of flaws.
But it represents the reality better.
That is, it matches what my eyes sees better than the cell phone logic generated photos.
Learned for myself, rather than pursuing skills and equipment to make photos like those of the professionals, make a photo or record of your own experience.
If the goal or the pursuit is to understand how light is captured and processed, then purchase a used DSLR and go take pictures of unique offerings in the neighborhood

text:
ğŸ“· What is a Camera Sensor?
A camera sensor is the electronic component inside a digital camera that captures light coming through the lens and converts it into an image.
Think of it like the digital version of film in old cameras.

title: Similar Outcome
text:
ğŸ” How It Works:

Light enters through the lens.
It hits the sensor, which is covered with millions of tiny light-sensitive units called photosites or pixels.
Each pixel measures the amount of light and color that hits it.
The sensor sends this data to your cameraâ€™s processor, which turns it into a digital image.

title: Similar Outcome
text:
ğŸ“ Key Sensor Terms:







Term
What It Means




Megapixels (MP)
How many million pixels the sensor has. More MPs = higher potential resolution.


Full-frame Sensor
Same size as 35mm film. Great low-light performance and shallow depth of field.


Crop Sensor (APS-C, Micro 4/3)
Smaller than full-frame. Brings distant subjects closer, but can be noisier in low light.


Dynamic Range
How well the sensor captures both dark shadows and bright highlights.


ISO Sensitivity
How sensitive the sensor is to light (controlled by ISO settings).

title: Similar Outcome
text:
ğŸ§  Why It Matters:

A larger sensor usually gives you better image quality, especially in low light.
It affects depth of field (how blurry your background can be).
It determines how much detail and clarity your camera can capture.

title: Language of Record
text:
At a chapel near the new Orem, Utah Temple, there is a bit of anticipation or excitement before a speaker begins.
Whether it will be in éŸ“èª(í•œêµ­ì–´) or the language spoken by over a billion people.
If the talk is in è‹±èª, no translation is offered.
Since it is the acquired or the native language the congregation.
If the speaker talks in Korean, a simultaneous translation is given using a wireless microphone/transmitter and received using headphone attached to a wireless receiver.
It wasnâ€™t always this way.
A generation ago, if the speaker chose English, a translator would stand next to the speaker. Then carefully and faithfully listen to the sentence and provide an interpretation.
That generation, who had learned the English but never fully integrated into society, is no longer.
According to an internet based data, there are one million Korean speakers in the United States.
During high school and college years, stating that I am from Korea drew a response as if I am from either Mars or some island in the Pacific.
My son said that peopleâ€™s knowledge of Korea changed.

title: Language of Record

Number of Korean Speakers
As of 2025, the Korean language is spoken by approximately 82 million people worldwide, making it one of the most widely spoken languages globally.


ğŸŒ Global Distribution of Korean Speakers
South Korea: Approximately 48 million native speakers.
North Korea: Around 24 million native speakers.
China: About 2 million speakers, primarily in the Yanbian Korean Autonomous Prefecture. (Korean language)
United States: Approximately 1 million speakers, especially concentrated in areas like Los Angelesâ€™ Koreatown. (Korean Language - Worldmapper)
Japan: Roughly 500,000 speakers, many of whom are part of the Zainichi Korean community.
Other Regions: Significant Korean-speaking communities exist in countries such as Russia (particularly in the Sakhalin region), Central Asia, and various parts of Europe and Oceania. (Korean language)



ğŸ—ºï¸ Official Status and Recognition
Official Language: Korean is the official language of both South Korea and North Korea. (Korean language | History, Characteristics, & Facts - Britannica)
Recognized Minority Language: In China, Korean holds official status in the Yanbian Korean Autonomous Prefecture in Jilin Province. (Korea)

ğŸ“ˆ Global Influence and Cultural Impact
The global popularity of Korean pop culture, known as the Korean Wave (Hallyu), has significantly increased interest in the Korean language. Institutions like the King Sejong Institute have been established worldwide to promote Korean language education and cultural exchange. (Korean language)
